proverbs.english: Who can compete with righteousness? It creates life.
If wickedness exerts itself, how will Utu succeed?
proverbs.sumerian: niĝ2-erim2-e a2-bi ḫe2-bi2-ib2-kuš2-u3 d-utu me-da tum3

proverbs.english: You should not cut the throat of that which has already had its throat cut.
You should not say to Nin-ĝiš-zi-da: 'Let me live!'
Do not make me pass through the gate!
What has submitted will exhibit resistance.
proverbs.sumerian: niĝ2 gu2 ĝar-ra niĝ2 gaba ĝar-ra

proverbs.english: What has been destroyed belongs to a god. No one is able to take it away.
proverbs.sumerian: niĝ2 ḫa-lam-ma diĝir-ra-kam šu tu-tu nu-ub-zu

proverbs.english: 'Though I still have bread left over, I will eat your bread!' Will this endear a man to the household of his friend?
proverbs.sumerian: ninda-ĝu10 ḫe2-ĝal2 ninda-zu ga-gu7[line] e2 dub3-sa-na-ka lu2 ba-ni-ib-kal-le

proverbs.english: If bread is left over, the mongoose eats it. If I have any bread left over, then a stranger will eat it.
proverbs.sumerian: ninda ḫe2-ĝal2-e d-nin-kilim ib2-gu7[line] ninda ḫa-ma-ĝal2-e lu2-kur2-ra ib2-gu7

proverbs.english: My things changed things.
You don't speak of that which you have found. You talk only about what you have lost.
proverbs.sumerian: niĝ2 i3-pad3-da-zu nu-ub-be2-en[line] niĝ2 u2-gu de2-a-zu ab-be2-en

proverbs.english: Something which has never occurred since time immemorial: a young woman did not fart in her husband's embrace.
proverbs.sumerian: niĝ2 ud-bi-ta la-ba-ĝal2-la[line] ki-sikil tur ur2 dam-ma-na-ka še10 nu-ub-dur2-re

proverbs.english: It is a thing of short duration.
Whatever it is that hurts you, don't talk to anyone about it.
Wealth is far away, poverty is close at hand.
He who possesses many things is constantly on guard.
Possessions make trust of crucial importance.
Possessions are flying birds -- they never find a place to settle.
Good fortune (is embedded in) ( reinforces) organisation and wisdom.
What is eaten for today was put there by the dog. What is eaten by the dog was put there for today .
proverbs.sumerian: niĝ2 ud-de3 gu7 ur-re ba-an-ĝar[line] niĝ2 ur-re gu7 ud-de3 ba-an-ĝar

proverbs.english: (One shouldn't) ( I will not) scorn bread which has turned bad.
Give out only half a loaf voluntarily!
To be wealthy and insist (?) on demanding more is abominable.
[line] line unclear
Let him decree the fates while consuming what you have made.
I always seem to be speaking about unpleasant things.
When a purchase is settled it is soon out of mind.
He did something never seen before.
That which does not eat grass is a wild bull of the mountains. That which does not drink water is a gazelle of the mountains.
proverbs.sumerian: [niĝ2] /u2\ nu-gu7 am kur-ra-ka[line] [niĝ2] a nu-naĝ maš-da3 kur-ra-ka

proverbs.english: One does not return borrowed bread.
The herald rejoices when the estate makes expenditures.
The steward rejoices when the estate increases its income.
Don't pick things now; they will bear fruit later.
Who will listen to your translations?
proverbs.sumerian: niĝ2 inim bal-e-en-na-zu[line] a-ba-am3 ĝiš mu-ra-an-tuku-tuku

proverbs.english: What you are doing is a small accomplishment. That man is not doing a man's work.
proverbs.sumerian: niĝ2 ab-ak-ak-na-zu niĝ2 ak tur lu2 ne in-nu

proverbs.english: Bread is served but it is not used for wiping. Water is poured out, and then drunk by the ground. In the nether world, the most honoured place, since it is water and food, it is called a water libation.
proverbs.sumerian: ninda i3-sig10 šu nu-un-gur[line] a ib2-ta-de2 ki-in-du ba-ab-naĝ[line] kur-ra ki kal-la-kal-la-ba[line] a-am3 u2-am3 a-de2-da mu-pad3-de3-dam

proverbs.english: Let his bread be foul food; no man should eat it.
Barley flour, in the fields, is meat fat.
Whatever food is available in the fields is to be eaten alone.
Chickpea-flour is appropriate for every woman in the palace.
His bread is finished.
There is no baked cake in the middle of the dough.
My heart urged me to bake two loaves out of a half. My hands were unable to take them out of the oven.[line] Bread is the boat, water is the punt-pole.
proverbs.sumerian: ninda 2(MIN) /MAŠ\-ta-am3 du8-u3-de3 šag4-ĝu10 am3-tum3-de3[line] šu-ĝu10 im.šu-rin-na-ta nu-ub-ta-ed2-de3[line] ninda ĝiš-ma2-am3 a ĝiš-gi-muš-am3

proverbs.english: Give me my tools and I will launch my boat.

Let the poor man die, let him not live. When he finds bread, he finds no salt. When he finds salt, he finds no bread. When he finds meat, he finds no condiments. When he finds condiments, he finds no meat. ( When he finds oil, he finds no jar. When he finds a jar, he finds no oil.)
proverbs.sumerian: ukur3 ḫa-ba-ug7 nam-ba-da-til3-i[line] ninda i3-pad3 mun nu-pad3 mun i3-pad3 ninda nu-pad3[line] uzu i3-pad3 gazi nu-pad3 gazi i3-pad3 uzu nu-pad3 ( i3 i3-pad3 šaĝan nu-pad3 šaĝan i3-pad3 i3 nu-pad3)

proverbs.english: When he walks on the streets no one greets him. And when he comes home to his wife, 'Bad Name' is what he is called.
proverbs.sumerian: e-sir2-ra ḫe2-du silim-eš2 gu3 nu-um-de2[line] e2-a i-ni-in-kur9 /nita.lam\-ma-ni-še3 mu ḫul mu-bi-/im\

proverbs.english: The lives of the poor do not survive their deaths.
For morsels of bread and fine onions, the food of the school (?).
proverbs.sumerian: ninda pax(PAD)-ra2 šum2-sikil zil2-la2-še3[line] ninda e2-dub?-/ba\-[a-kam]

proverbs.english: In the city where there are no dogs, the fox is boss.
In the city of the lame, a cripple is the courier.
The city's fate cannot be determined; its book-keeper is a merchant.
You should drive them like pack-asses into a death-stricken city.
When you are expelled from a city, that city and its king are carried off.
The songs of a city are its diviners.
When I enter a sleeping city, the city will be filled with blood. When I board a deep-draught boat, it will go aground.
proverbs.sumerian: iri-ki u3 ku-a ga-am3-kur9 iri-ki mud ba-e-si[line] /ĝiš\ma2-su3-a ga-ab-u5[line] [peš10] /mu\-un-tag-tag-ge-de3

proverbs.english: The merchant left the city and the market broke up.
Things may be traded in the city but it is the fisherman who brings in the food supply.
proverbs.sumerian: iri-a niĝ2 bal-bal ba-an-ĝar šu-KU6-de3 šukur2 ba-an-dab5-be2-eš

proverbs.english: The name of the city is Idibi. Its king's name is Didibi. Its queen's name is No-good-at-all.
proverbs.sumerian: iri i-di-bi mu-bi-im[line] lugal-bi di-di-bi mu-bi-im[line] nin-bi nu-dug3-dug3-ga mu-bi-im

proverbs.english: Like a clod thrown into the water, may it be destroyed as it disintegrates.
Beer is a bull. The mouth is its stairway.
He hurled his insult. He laid his curse.

To a curse that is uttered, a curse is not reciprocated. (A curse which is reciprocated will be retaliated against with yet another curse.) ((1 ms. has instead:) The curse with which I would respond would cause another curse to be uttered.)
proverbs.sumerian: aš2 dug4-dug4-ge aš2 nu-mu-ni-in-gi4[line] (aš2-e gi4-a aš2-a ba-ni-in-gi4) ((1 ms. has instead:) aš2 šu gi4-a-ĝu10 aš2 mu-un-dug4)

proverbs.english: It is an insult resulting from an insult. It is a curse resulting from a curse. It is the constant renewal of destiny.
proverbs.sumerian: in-na in-bi-im aš2-e aš2-bi-im[line] nam-tar-ra ki gibil-gibil-la2-bi

proverbs.english: To accept a verdict is possible. To accept a curse is impossible.
proverbs.sumerian: di gid2-i al-ĝal2 aš2 gid2-i nu-ĝal2

proverbs.english: What has been spoken in secret will be revealed in the women's quarters.
When a trustworthy boat is sailing, Utu seeks out a trustworthy harbour for it.
proverbs.sumerian: ĝiš-ma2 niĝ2-gen6-na ni2 ba-ra-ab-dirig[line] d-utu kar gen6-na mu-un-na-ab-ši-kiĝ2-kiĝ2

proverbs.english: When a dishonest boat is sailing, it runs aground.
proverbs.sumerian: ĝiš-ma2 niĝ2-erim2-e ni2 ba-ra-ab-dirig[line] peš10-peš10-e im-ta-/tag\-[tag]-e

proverbs.english: A ferryboat sank at Zabalam. 'Oh Utu of Larsam, who pulled out the mooring stake?'
proverbs.sumerian: [ĝiš]ma2-/addir\ zab.alam.ki-a ba-su[line] d-utu lar.sam.ki-ma a-ba-a ĝiš ba-da-an-zig3

proverbs.english: A boatman -- belligerence.
If the boat sinks, I will pull out the cargo.
Like a boat, he always floats up in the water.
My girlfriend's heart is a heart made for me.
In my heart you are a human being, but in my eyes you are not a man.
When the heart overflows, it is lamentable. (He who can keep it in his heart is a prince.) ((1 ms. has instead:) I am a prince who can keep it in the heart.)
proverbs.sumerian: šag4-ga ub-dirig a-nir-ra[line] (šag4-ga sig10-ga dumu lugal-la-ka) ((1 ms. has instead:) /šag4\-ga sig10-ga dumu /lugal-la-me\-[en])

proverbs.english: Those who get excited should not become foremen. A shepherd should not become a farmer.
proverbs.sumerian: šag4-bi zig3-ga ugula nam-me[line] sipad engar nam-me

proverbs.english: What comes out from the heart of the tree is known by the heart of the tree.
proverbs.sumerian: šag4 ĝiš-a-ta e3-a[line] šag4 ĝiš-a-ta zu-am3

proverbs.english: He is at ease, he is pleased, he makes a living, he offers a prayer.
proverbs.sumerian: šag4-ge ba-dug3 bar-re ba-sag9[line] gu7-e ba-te šudu3?-e ba-gid2-i

proverbs.english: Whether he ate it or not, the seed was good.
He broke it into pieces and sated his hunger. He licked his hands and belched.
proverbs.sumerian: in-pad šag4 an-dirig šu bi2-in-/sub!\[line] bu-lu-uḫ2 mu-un-si-il-si-il-e

proverbs.english: He who drinks beer drinks water.
He who eats too much cannot sleep.
If one pours oil into the inside of a sceptre ((2 mss. add:) nobody will know.)
proverbs.sumerian: šag4 ĝidru-ka i3 ḫe2-en-de2 ((2 mss. add:) lu2 na-me nu-/zu\)

proverbs.english: A heart never created hatred; speech created hatred.
proverbs.sumerian: šag4-ge šag4 ḫul gig nu-ub-tu-ud[line] dug4-ge šag4 ḫul gig ib2-tu-ud

proverbs.english: Let it be plentiful, so that it is not deficient. Let it be excessive, so that it does not have to be supplemented. Let it be piping hot, so that it does not become cold.
proverbs.sumerian: ḫe2-lu-a nam-ba-la2[line] ḫe2-dirig na-an-su-su[line] ḫe2-eb-šeĝ6 na-an-te-en-te-en

proverbs.english: Inwardly a ewe, outwardly a ewe, a most fecund spouse: 'Let the shepherd perish, but may you not perish.'
proverbs.sumerian: šag4 u8 bar u8 mu-ud-na lum-ma-lum-ma[line] sipad ḫe2-en-ḫa-lam za-e na-an-ḫa-lam-e-de3

proverbs.english: You cannot butt me with your horns! Who is it that you are butting? You cannot kill me -- I am running away!
proverbs.sumerian: si nu-mu-e-da-a-il2-/i\[line] a-ba-/am3\ si il2-i-de3-nam[line] ĝe26-e nu-mu-e-da-gaz i-ni-du-du-[de3-en]

proverbs.english: Across the heavens , across the earth, litter (anba) is distributed (anba) over the earth.(based on puns)
proverbs.sumerian: an bal ki bal an-ba ki an-ba

proverbs.english: [line] line unclear
[line] line fragmentary
proverbs.sumerian: BU-UD-bar U3 BA MA X [X] X X

proverbs.english: A trough for kneading dough, not kept clean.
A trough from which the pigs eat.
My husband heaps up for me, my child measures out for me; let my lover pick the bones from the fish for me.
A plant as sweet as a husband does not grow in the steppe.
Oh my sister, if there were no outdoor shrines, and, oh my mother, if there were no river as well, I would be dying of hunger.
proverbs.sumerian: nin9-ĝu10 ub-lil2-la2 nam-me-a[line] ama-ĝu10 id2-da nam-ga-me-am3[line] šaĝar-da ba-ug7-e-de3-en-e-še

proverbs.english: You are not one who stays in one place, you are one who is everywhere.
proverbs.sumerian: aĝ2 ki di-ta nu-/ĝen\ aĝ2 ki šar2-ra-ĝen

proverbs.english: Accept your lot and make your mother happy. Run fast and make your god happy.
proverbs.sumerian: ĝiš-šub us2-sa-ab ama-zu ḫul2-la-ab[line] kaš4 dug4-ga-ab diĝir-zu ḫul2-la-ab

proverbs.english: Marry a wife according to your choice. Have children to your heart's content.
proverbs.sumerian: igi il2-la-zu dam tuku-ba-ni-ib[line] šag4-ge guru7-zu dumu tuku-ba-ni-ib

proverbs.english: May Inana make a hot-limbed wife lie with you! May she bestow upon you broad-shouldered sons! May she seek out for you a happy place!
proverbs.sumerian: din.an.a-ke4 dam ur2 kum2-ma ḫa-ra-nu2-a[line] dumu a2 tal2-tal2-la ḫa-ra-an-ba-e[line] ki niĝ2 sag9-ga ḫa-ra-an-kiĝ2-kiĝ2-/e\

proverbs.sumerian: ki-sikil šeš-zu saĝ nu-mu-re-eb-kal-le[line] a-ba-am3 saĝ mu-e-kal-le-en

proverbs.english: Girl, your brother is like me. A brother should let you live as would I.
proverbs.sumerian: ki-sikil šeš-zu ĝe26-e-gin7-nam[line] šeš ĝe26-gin7 ḫe2-til3-le

proverbs.english: When I married a malicious husband, when I bore a malicious son, an unhappy heart was assigned to me.
proverbs.sumerian: dam nu-ĝar-ra tuku-a-ĝu10-ne[line] dumu nu-ĝar-ra tud-da-ĝu10-ne[line] šag4 nu-dug3-ga ma-a-še3? ma-an-ĝar

proverbs.english: He who does not support a wife, he who does not support a child, has no cause for celebration.
proverbs.sumerian: dam nu-il2 dumu nu-il2[line] giri17-zal-še3 nu-il2

proverbs.english: A malicious wife living in the house is worse than all diseases.
proverbs.sumerian: dam nu-ĝar-ra e2-a til3-la-am3[line] a2-sag3-a2-sag3-e dirig-ga-am3

proverbs.english: Conceived by no father, conceived by no mother, the enbar reed came out of the eye of the storm.
proverbs.sumerian: ad-da-a a ḫur nu-ri[line] ama-a a ḫur nu-ri[line] gien3-bar gaba ud-da-ka e3-a

proverbs.sumerian: nitaḫ zig3-ga-am3 mun al-gu7-e[line] munus zig3-ga-am3 im-ma al-gid2-gid2-de3

proverbs.english: A disorderly son -- his mother should not have given birth to him. His god should not have created him.
proverbs.sumerian: dumu si nu-sa2 ama-a-ni na-an-u3-tud[line] diĝir-ra-ni na-an-dim2-dim2-e

proverbs.english: My wife said 'Unfaithful!' to me -- shall I go chasing after women's genitals?
An unfaithful penis matches (?) an unfaithful vagina.
Marrying is human. Having children is divine.
proverbs.sumerian: dam tuku-tuku lu2-ulu3-/ka?\[line] dumu tuku-tuku diĝir-ra-/ka?\

proverbs.english: Oh merchant, how you use up silver! And how you use up barley!
proverbs.sumerian: dam-gar3-re kug ta ba-an-ir[line] u3 še ta ba-an-ir

proverbs.english: At the top it is a wild cow, at the bottom it is a fish. At the top it is shattered potsherds, at the bottom it is half a cubit.
proverbs.sumerian: an sumun2?-am3 ki ku6-am3[line] an šika de5 ki MAŠ kuš3

proverbs.english: I visit it by day, I visit it at nightfall. I always stand by the lamentation drum!
proverbs.sumerian: ud i3-di-di-in ud šu2-uš i3-di-di-in[line] balaĝ er2-ra im-ma-gub-gub-bu-de3-en

proverbs.english: Sons-in-law -- what have they brought? Fathers-in-law -- what have they disposed of?
proverbs.sumerian: mi2-sa2-tur ta mu-un-ir-ra-bi[line] ušbar-e ta bi2-in-bur2-ra-bi

proverbs.english: She who says 'My expense' is her girl friend. An interfering neighbour is the one with whom she quarrels.
proverbs.sumerian: zig3-ga-ĝu10 dug4-ga ma-la-ga-ni[line] ušur na de5-ga lu2 du14-da-ka-ni

proverbs.english: In the seventh month he did not slaughter a pig. In the sixth month he did not put on a new turban.
proverbs.sumerian: itid du6-kug-ga-ka šaḫ2 nu-un-X[line] itid kiĝ2-ga-ša-an-an-na-ka aga? gibil! nu-um-mur10

proverbs.english: I walk about, I don't get tired. I keep moving, I don't sleep.
When the rags have been cut up, when the barley is lying in the dust, what is there left to get?
proverbs.sumerian: tug2-me-ze2-er-ra ba-da-ab-bir7-ra[line] še saḫar-ra ba-da-an-til3-la[line] ta-a šu ba-ni-ti

proverbs.english: I am a lady who wears large garments. Let me cut my loincloth!
When you are eating, may nothing lack. When you are in need of water, may things not dry up.
proverbs.sumerian: aĝ2 gu7-gu7-ĝen aĝ2 nam-la2-e[line] /tur?-ra?\-ĝen aĝ2 nam-ba-ša-ra-ge-«en»

proverbs.english: A chattering girl is silenced by her mother. A chattering boy is not silenced by his mother.
proverbs.sumerian: ki-sikil gu3 ra-aḫ ama-ni mu-un-sig9[line] ĝuruš lu2 gu3 ra-aḫ ama-ni nu-mu-un-da-an-sig9

proverbs.english: His gathered brushwood will be carried off. His destroyed parapet (will) ( will not) be plundered.
proverbs.sumerian: u2 il2-la-a-ni ba-da-ab-il2-e[line] bad3-si gul-la-ni (šu mu-un-ak-e) ( šu? nu-mu-na-ab-ak?-e?)

proverbs.english: Food is the matter, water is the matter.
Fatty meat is good. Fatty mutton is good. -- What shall (I) ((1 ms. has instead:) we) give the slave girl?
proverbs.sumerian: uzu.suš2 al-/ze2-eb\[line] uzui3-udu al-/ze2\-eb[line] ta-am3 gi4-in-na ( ga-an-na-ab-ze2-eĝ3-ĝen ) ((1 ms. has instead:) ga-ma-ze2-ĝe26-e-en-de3-en )

proverbs.english: Let her eat the ham of a pig!
You are pouring the fat from the meat, you are pulling out the roasted barley -- when you carry the cooking pot, watch out for your feet!
proverbs.sumerian: uzu i3 ab-ta-/ab\-bal-e-en[line] še sa-a bi2-ib-ze2-re-/en\[line] lu2 utul2 da-il2-la me-ri-za en-nu-uĝ3 ak-ab-e-še

proverbs.english: To be sick is acceptable; to be pregnant is painful; but to be pregnant and sick is just too much.
She has risen high, but cannot go on. She is low, but cannot rise.
proverbs.sumerian: an-še3 i3-zig3 nu-mu-un-da-ma-ma[line] ki-še3 i3-ma-al nu-mu-un-da-zi-zi-i

proverbs.english: A brewing trough not previously tried is put to the test by means of salt. A mixing jar not previously tried is put to the test by means of water. A son-in-law whose behaviour is unknown is put to the test by means of quarrels.
proverbs.sumerian: utul2 du-bu-ul nu-zu mun?-ta um?-/ta?\-sig10[line] dug sur-ra nu-zu a-ta al-/sig10\[line] mi2-sa2 niĝ2-DI nu-un-zu-a du14 mu2-mu2 al-sig10

proverbs.english: The master knows. The steward does not know.
May the master sleep at your side, and may the mistress slap your face.
proverbs.sumerian: lugal-e da ḫa-ra-/nu2\ u3 nin-e muš3-me-zu ḫe2-eb-ra

proverbs.english: The lord and lady of the house touch the figurine.
proverbs.sumerian: lugal e2-e u3 nin e2-e-ke4 ĝiš-za-na mi-ni-ib-tag-ge-ne

proverbs.english: The granary collects.
Outgoings are a matter for both, and now I also am one of them.
[line] lines unclear
proverbs.sumerian: /AB?\ šag4? ĝiš-ur3?-bi DE2-a-ka[line] lu2 usu-bi? e2-a-na-ka

proverbs.english: Their masters have changed. They are dressed in mourning (?) clothes.
Thus says the man whose clothes are torn: 'Precious things are strong.'
proverbs.sumerian: lu2 tug2 bir7-bir7-ra na-ab-be2-a[line] kal-kal-la al-kal-la-ge-e-še

proverbs.english: A man who can lift the heavens -- and he does not fart.
A man who behaves like a damp reed towards his fellow men does not tell the truth either.
proverbs.sumerian: lu2 gi duru5 ak-gin7 lu2-lu2-u3-ra[line] niĝ2-gen6-na inim nu-mu-un-da-ab-bal-e

proverbs.english: The man whose knees are paralysed has not prayed devoutly to Nintur.
proverbs.sumerian: lu2 dug3 dab5-ba d-nin-tur5-re[line] inim-ma nu-[mu]-/na\-an-sig10-e-še

proverbs.english: He whose barley sprouts weeps. He who is pouring out water cannot converse.
proverbs.sumerian: lu2 še lum-lum er2 al-še8-še8[line] lu2 a de2-a ka-bi nu-ba-e

proverbs.english: A man who didn't tie up his leather sack made his friend angry.
proverbs.sumerian: lu2 kuš.a2-ĝa2-la2-ni nu-keše2-da gu5-li-ni-da šag4 bi2-in-dab5

proverbs.english: Even a millstone will float in the river for a righteous man.
proverbs.sumerian: lu2 si sa2-ra na4-kinkin(ḪAR) id2-da mu-na-ab-dirig-dirig

proverbs.english: The thief, out of fear of facing a lion, becomes a man driven by fear of facing a lion cub.
proverbs.sumerian: lu2-zuḫ-a ni2 igi piriĝ-ĝa2-ka[line] lu2 [ḫub2] sar-re ni2 igi piriĝ-tur-[ra]-ka

proverbs.english: The thief extends winter to the beginning of summer.
When a burglar makes a hole, he makes it narrow.
The owner of a house should reinforce the windows against burglars.
Even the strongest labourer gets beaten by the owner of the barley.
A crafty man does not transgress against his mother.
A crafty man lays on a party for his neighbour.
A crafty man exhorts the crowd: 'Seize him! Drive him away!'
The crafty one hung whatever precious metal there was about herself .
A stone to a crafty man is two halves of a shekel.
A lame man spoke to his mother: 'Where a man reclines in a chair, it is really comfortable!' His mother replied: 'What is he afraid of? When did we last see you run away anywhere?'
proverbs.sumerian: kud-ku5-ra2 ama-/ni\ na-ab-be2-a[line] ki gu-za lu2 i3-nu2 ĝiri3-pax-ra2-ni na-ab-/sag9\[line] /ama-ni\ na-ab-be2-[a][line] [a]-na-am3 ni2 te-ni-gin7[line] ḫub2 sar-re-zu igi u3-bi2-in-du8-un-de3-en-e-še

proverbs.english: A dog which knows no home.

In the city with no dogs, the fox is boss.
In the city of the lame, the cripple is a courier.
How does a cripple stand up?
The good thing is to find it; the bad thing is to lose it.
I have found it -- a cause for celebration! I have lost it -- my heart does not ache!
The good thing is the beer. The bad thing is the journey.
For his pleasure he got married. On his thinking it over he got divorced.
Their pleasure -- their discomfort. Their discomfort -- their pleasure.
Collecting firewood is for the strong man; the weak man waits for him on dry land.

The palace is a huge river; its interior is a goring bull.

proverbs.english: May you be a household built up by twin sons.
I would rather go home.
Those who enter his house are fifty.
Whom can I bring to a house whose offspring have been annihilated?
I don't return to a house whose master is not at home.
A bird in the sky is as good as an um bird.
A fish in the deep is as good as a carp in the reeds.
Four-legged creatures are as good as marsh rats.
All the birds flew away, and their mother alone stayed.
Ninazu, a bird flying around is your share.
In the fowler's trap (?) is what he eats.
He who lives from birds and fish cannot sleep.
He sneaks into the water like an um bird.
The wood pigeon's (?) voice is the glory of the garden.
The francolin's voice is the glory of the fields.
Offerings are the glory of the gods.
The arabu fowl was not eaten in time.
Now, you should not sleep in the reedbeds: the marsh rats will eat you.
Don't pour water into a river. The rats will come up.
Two esig birds, two (gusura fish) ((1 ms. has instead:) gusura birds), three suḫur carp, two eštub carp, and two suḫur carp, ((1 ms. adds:) two) sea fish, are present on Enlil's offering table.

While you still have light, grind the flour.
The wild bull is taboo for the plough.

You speak with me and I speak with you.

The two of them are like one man.
Were he to find where I put my rubbish heap, he would say: 'You shouldn't go there!'
Although it has never been there, the goat knows the wasteland.
With my mouth I cool the hot soup for you. I pick the bones from the fish for you.

proverbs.sumerian: gud-de3 mur-ra gub[line] amar-ta e2-ubur-/ra\ ba-ni-in-kur9

Offerings create life.
Punishment is assigned for the swaggerer; he is afflicted with diseases.
Let him go down.
You should hold a kid in your right arm, and a bribe in your left arm.
proverbs.sumerian: a2 zid-da-zu maš2 ḫe2-da-ĝal2[line] gab2-bu-zu kadra ḫe2-da-ĝal2

The sail on the mast blocks the river.
May you find the response to an insult hurled at you in a dispute.
If it is too sweet for him, let him eat salt. If it is not too sweet for him, let him eat licorice.
proverbs.sumerian: an-na-dug3-ga mun ḫe2-gu7-e[line] nu-un-na-dug3-ga u2-munzer ḫe2-gu7-e

proverbs.english: As long as the boasters haven't departed, their mouths make me uneasy.

proverbs.english: The rigging is not ship-shape, and the stern is not seaworthy.
He who entered Elam -- his lips are sealed.
He who has to live in Elam -- his life is not good.
Wheat and hulled barley was made to taste like honey. The nomad ate it and didn't recognise what was in it.

'Those things which make you happy!' it was told. 'Well then, let me go back again tonight and receive something!' And so, upon his return, his leg was again broken. He dragged his tail and sat in the street. A second time he questioned his tail: 'Did the bolt just come out from in front of you, like before?'

proverbs.english: The lord's wife kneels, the slave girl dies. The lord kneels, the slave dies.
proverbs.sumerian: dam u3-mu-un-si gam-am3 am ug5-ga-am3[line] [u3]-/mu\-un-si gam-am3 /arad\ ug5-ga-am3

proverbs.english: What did Enlil make? Chaff! The lance struck. It went into the flesh.
When the sun is setting outside so that you cannot even recognise the hand in front of you, go inside!
proverbs.sumerian: d-utu bar-ra ḫe2-en-ni-šu2 ni2-zu šu nu-zu-a kur9-ni-ib

proverbs.english: Accept your lot and make your mother happy! Run fast and make your god happy!
proverbs.sumerian: ĝiš-šub us2-sa ama-zu ḫul2-la[line] kaš4 <dug4>-ga-ab diĝir-zu ḫul2-la

proverbs.english: Marry the wife of your choice.
May Inana make a hot-limbed wife lie with you! May she bestow upon you broad-shouldered sons! May she find for you a place of happiness!
proverbs.sumerian: din.an.a-ke4 dam ur2 kum2-ma ḫa-ra-an-nu2-e[line] dumu a2 tal2-tal2-la ḫa-ra-an-ba-e[line] ki niĝ2 sag9-ga ḫa-ra-ab-kiĝ2-kiĝ2-e

proverbs.english: A plant as sweet as a husband, a plant as sweet as a mother: may Ezina-Kusu (the grain goddess) dwell in your home.
proverbs.sumerian: u2 dam-da ze2-eb u2 ama-da ze2-eb[line] de.zi.na2-dku3-su3 e2-a ḫe2-me-da-an-til3

proverbs.english: A man's waterskin is his life. A man's sandals are his eyes. A man's wife is his supervisor (?). A man's son is his protective shade. A man's daughter is his eager servant (?). A man's daughter-in-law is his policeman.
proverbs.sumerian: kuš-um-mud zi lu2-kam kuš-e-sir2 /igi\ lu2-kam[line] dam dim4-ma lu2-kam dumu-nitaḫ ĝissu lu2-kam[line] dumu-munus saĝ šu ĝar lu2-kam e2-gi4-a gal5-la2 lu2-kam

proverbs.english: The um bird flees, running away from its own behind.
When the mistress left the house and the slave girl entered from the street, away from her mistress the slave girl set up her own banquet.
proverbs.sumerian: e2-ta e3 sila-ta kur9-/ra\ geme2 nin-a-ni ĝiš-bum-ma-/ni\ [bi2-in-tuš]

proverbs.english: The litter was not apparent to the slave girl. To her mistress it just kept increasing.
A fool who was overwhelmed by his backside stuck his hand up his backside.
proverbs.sumerian: is-ḫab2 ki-bid3-/da\ [(X)] šu ša-an-ša-[ša-da][line] šu-ni bid3-/da\ [ba-ni-in-gid2]

proverbs.english: A great river is a grave.
From the horizon to the very heart of the heavens, the bread is too little for his great stomach! The grain from every hand in his Land is too little for him!
proverbs.sumerian: /an?-ur2? an?-šag4?-ga?\ ninda /šag4\-gal-la-ni-še3 bi2-in-tur[line] /šu\ kalam-ma-ni-ta še ba-an-da-tur

proverbs.english: Morsels of bread and tasty onions are the food of the school (?).
proverbs.sumerian: ninda pad-pax(PAD)-ra2 šum2-sikil zil2-la2 ninda e2-dub-ba-a

proverbs.english: In the fields, coarse flour is meat fat.
You should lift it all together, but put it down in pieces.
The early working shepherd, the early working farmer, the young man who got married while he was young: who compares to them?
proverbs.sumerian: sipad šu-nim-ma engar šu-nim-ma[line] ĝuruš-e ud tur-ra-na-/ka\ dam ba-tuku-tuku-u2-a[line] /a\-ba-a /mu\-da-ab-sa2-e
